millsfield:images_texts:
The Statue of Liberty
1886 - 1986
Dong
KingmHn

The Statue of Liberty will officially celebrate her 100th birthday on October 28, 1986. On this day in history, 100 years
ago, the Statue of Liberty was dedicated by President Grover Cleveland. Over the years, her symbolism has grown to include
freedom, liberty and a special meaning for the more than 17 million immigrants that passed through Ellis Island between
1892 and 1954.
Eduard de Laboulaye is often called the "Father of the Statue of Liberty" because he initially proposed the concept in
1865. Sculptor Frederic Auguste Bartholdi was commissioned to design the statue. With the assistance of Gustave Eiffel, who
designed the iron framework and is better known for his later work "The Eiffel Tower", the statue was completed in France in
1884. The cost of the statue was $400,000, which was paid for by contributions from the French people.
This unique statue was presented to the American Ambassador by the people of France on July 4, 1884, in recognition of
the friendship established between the two nations. In the summer of 1885, the Statue was dismantled into 350 individual
pieces and shipped to America on the French frigate "Isére" in 214 separate crates.
In August of 1885 the $270,000 needed to build the pedestal and re-assemble the statue was raised by the Ameri-
can people. The chosen site for the statue was Bedloe's Island, now known as Liberty Island. Construction of the pedestal
which was designed by Richard Morris Hunt began soon thereafter and was completed in April of 1886.
On January 1, 1892, the Ellis Island Immigration Station opened and continued to operate until 1954 when it was de-
clared surplus government property. Ellis Island, which lies nearby Liberty Island, was merely 3 acres of sand and silt that
was barely visible at high tide when it was bought by the U.S. Government in 1808. Today, Ellis Island is largely a man-made
island covering 27½ acres.
On October 15, 1924, the Statue of Liberty was declared a National Monument by Presidential Proclamation. In 1954,
work began to create a museum at the base of The Lady and in 1965 Ellis Island became a part of the Statue of Liberty
National Monument.
The watercolor on this menu was specially created for the celebration of the
100th Anniversary of the Statue of Liberty by the world renowned artist, Dong
Kingman who was born in California and educated in Hong Kong. His watercolor
paintings have graced more than forty major museums and numerous private collec-
tions in the U.S.A. and abroad.
